entry.title: How far will AI go... and what will it mean for your job?
entry.content:
In April this year, I decided to voluntarily retire early from SAP after 6 years of a very interesting journey. Indeed, I've lived from the inside the infusion of powerful Artificial Intelligence capabilities in SAP Build, for application development and for process automation.

Since then, I've spent 8 months observing the IT industry evolution, particularly around AI. And now, I have very mixed feelings:

‚úîÔ∏è On one hand, I'm impressed how well SAP is positioned on the market and how SAP AI is powerful

‚ùì On the other hand, I'm more and more worried by the impact humanoid robots and AI, from SAP and all vendors, will have on so many jobs everywhere.

So I decided to share my views with you in this blog post.

SAP is amazingly well positioned with Business AI

A month ago I watched SAP TechEd Keynote and also a few sessions, and I have to say that I'm impressed. By the way, in case you missed it, watch the replay of the keynote:

I discovered AI more than 40 years ago, when I was studying to graduate in 1986 as an engineer in computing science, and 10 years ago I was working for Antidot, a french startup involved in knowledge graphs, where I wrote this white paper on Business Knowledge Graphs in 2014.

So, from my humble point of view, putting together SAP ERP + SAP Business Data Cloud + SAP Knowledge Graphs + SAP Business AI with Joule creates a winning combo. It puts SAP in a unique position , better than any competitor, to bring the best of AI to the customers.

And what has been presented and announced at SAP TechEd makes SAP even stronger:

SAP-ABAP-1 is a new model allowing to handle ABAP language: trained on more than 250 million lines of ABAP code, 30 million lines of CDS code, and extensive technical documentation, it is purpose-built to explain and generate modern ABAP code.

SAP-RPT-1 (Relational Pre-trained Transformer Model-1) is a brand new classification and regression model, allowing to better handle structured, tabular business data. It is a paradigm shift in machine learning, introducing a revolutionary approach that eliminates the security-performance trade-off entirely. SAP-RPT-1 achieves state-of-the-art performance and already outperforms regular text-based LLMs through semantic understanding of tabular relationships.

Knowledge Graph in SAP HANA Cloud is an RDF graph built from system catalog, capturing tables, columns, relationships, and annotations. It providesthe semantic layer needed for exploration, AI grounding, and graph-based reasoning. It allows agents to reason about data, to understand entities relationships, and which attributes are relevant. 

A2A and MCP protocols foster Agentic AI by allowing autonomous agents collaboration: SAP is providing out-of-the-box Joule agents and alllowing customers to create custom agents with Agent Builder in Joule Studio. Beyond that, agentic protocols such as A2A - Agent to Agent - and MCP - Model Context Protocol - with SAP Lean IX Agent Hub and Agent Mining in SAP Signavio allow to standardize, deploy and monitor AI agents collaboration.

To dig deeper on these topics, follow the links I've put in the text above, watch the replay of the SAP TechEd sessions and also refer to

  • SAP  Innovation Guide
  • SAP Guide "What is Joule?" 

And to give you something to think about, this video on LinkedIn from SAP shows how far collaboration between an AI and a humanoid robot can go:

What impact will AI have on human employment?

So, we all agree, SAP is doing very well with Business AI for empowering companies to do better and faster. And this is very good for SAP and its entire ecosystem.

But when it comes to employees working in these companies, things could be different. Indeed, some news popping up in mainstream media are a bit worrying. For instance, according to McKinsey & Company, AI can already do almost 60% of all the work:

Their research ‚ÄúAgents, robots, and us: Skill partnerships in the age of AI‚Äù says that the future of work will be basically shaped by partnerships among people, agents, and robots - all powered by AI. The research emphasizes that capturing AI‚Äôs massive potential economic value - about $2.9 trillion by 2023 in the US only! - depends entirely on how organizations will reorganize.

Indeed, be it for business users, for consultants, for developers, AI agents will be everywhere... and they will do a lot of tasks done by human employees today.

And we have already seen this year how big tech firms have "reorganized" to embrace AI benefits: 

  • Amazon - 30,000 layoffs
  • Accenture - 11,000 layoffs
  • Microsoft - 6,000 layoffs
  • HP - 4,000-6000 layoffs

So in total more than 50,000 jobs have been erased in a few months only. And SAP as well is shrinking its workforce: ‚ÄúIn one year, it could be one or sometimes two percent of jobs that are eliminated‚Äù said Christian Klein, and Dominik Asam  added ‚ÄúThere are certain tasks which are automated and for the same volume of output we can afford to have less people". He admits to be "brutal",  comparing this program to routines such as brushing teeth...

We're reading more and more that AI could significantly impact the job market for junior professionals and entry-level positions in many knowledge-based professions, including IT/SAP consultants and JavaScript or ABAP developers.

In France, for example, a quarter of business leaders already report that entry-level positions were reduced or eliminated last year due to the efficiency gains generated by these tools.

But today's and tomorrow's junior professionals will need to learn the ropes to become the senior professionals of the day after tomorrow; otherwise, who will be experienced enough to mentor and lead AI in 2050?

Because, in 2050, if I'm not dead, I'll be 87 years old, so don't count on me. üòâ

Meanwhile, it seems everyone is trying to reassure the public that everything will be fine‚Ä¶ perhaps to prevent tens of millions of workers from becoming upset about the prospect of losing their jobs?

Should not a part of the value created by all the AI software and humanoid robots be used to compentiate this massive loss of jobs?

Today, in many countries, health insurance, unemployment insurance, and pensions are financed by contributions paid by employers and employees on human work. If the number of employees is decreasing, shouldn't social security contributions be levied on the work performed by AI agents and humanoid robots?

Will robots embrace Karl Marx slogan? üôÉ

What do you think? How do you envision the impact AI and robots will have on your job in 3, 5 or 10 years?

Your feedback will be highly appreciated, so feel free to share your own views in the comments!

entry.title: Setting Up Joule Studio for All Partner Flows and Entitlement Levels
entry.content:
This blog was authored by Joule Studio Product Managers: Charan Ravikumar and Maria Kondratyeva

 

Setting Up Joule Studio for All Partner Flows and Entitlement Levels

Joule Studio, the latest capability in SAP Build, empowers developers to extend SAP's AI copilot with custom Joule skills and powerful Joule agents tailored to your unique business needs. These capabilities extend Joule, orchestrate complex cross-functional workflows, and unlock new levels of enterprise efficiency.

However, we recognize that the partner landscape, with its mix of TDD, PAYG, and subscription accounts, introduces unique complexities. Many of you have asked the essential question: "How do we, as partners, get Joule Studio set up correctly in our environments?"

This guide is built specifically for you. It synthesizes insights from our support channels and direct partner feedback to address your most common challenges, such as multi-global account integrations and navigating the new SAP Build licensing in TDD environments. Whether you're starting fresh or integrating existing services, this post outlines everything you need to know to get started efficiently and cost-effectively.

Let's get started!

Critical Prerequisites: Licensing & Plans

Before diving into the setup flows, let's clarify three critical concepts that are often sources of confusion for partners. Getting these right from the start will save you significant time and effort.

The "New" SAP Build Plan (build-default)

Many partners have existing SAP Build entitlements on a legacy "standard" plan. To use Joule Studio, you must use the build-default plan, specifically for SAP Build Process Automation.

  • Critical Action: Do NOT order a new, separate SAP Build subscription! In your existing Partner TDD Global Account (under a PAYG model), the entitlement for the new plan is already available.
    • You simply need to navigate to the Service Marketplace in your BTP cockpit and activate the SAP Build Process Automation service, ensuring you select the build-default plan during setup.
  • Note: Ordering a new subscription instead of activating the existing entitlement often leads to selecting the wrong plan and creates unnecessary account complexity.
  • TDD Licensing Options:
    • License the Pay-As-You-Go for SAP BTP for cloud test, demo, and development (SKU 8009282). This grants you access to free "Fair Use Limits" for SAP Build (Recommended)
    • Alternative (Subscription): A subscription-based SAP Build TDD developer license (SKU 8019951) is also available, but it does not include the Fair Use Limits.
  • What is Fair Use Limits (FUL): The Fair Use Limit where the partner is provided an entitled specified threshold amount of TDD services free of charge per billing cycle. It‚Äôs designed to support development without unexpected costs.
    • Please refer to this link for more details on FUL - https://partneredge.sap.com/en/library/assets/products/tech_plat/dgl/30/23/SAP1223023.html

  Joule Entitlement 

    • TDD Joule Base SKU: 8020592
    • Joule for Consultant and Joule for Developers are different licenses and not connected with Joule Studio license and its activation.

  • For Custom Joule Skills: There is no additional cost for the orchestration and invocation of custom Joule Skills using the current features in Joule Studio. This means you do not need AI Units to run custom Joule Skills in your production environments.

  • For Custom Joule Agents: Following the promotion throughout January 2026, the execution of custom Joule Agents in production will consume AI Units.

  • It‚Äôs important to note that for both custom skills and agents, the underlying components they use will still follow their standard commercial models. For example, if your custom Joule skill or agent kicks off a business process automation, the usage of SAP Build Process Automation will still be billed according to its pricing structure.

The Multi-Global Account Scenario

It is very common for partners to have their Joule entitlement in a TDD subscription based global account and their SAP Build entitlement in a separate TDD PAYG global account. This is a supported scenario.

  • The Golden Thread: The key to making this work is to ensure that both global accounts are federated under the same SAP Cloud Identity Services (IAS). This single identity provider is what allows the two systems to trust each other and integrate seamlessly.
  • To run Joule Booster or Joule Formation (see table below), select the 2 global accounts you have.

Understanding Your Integration Flow: Starting Points and Required Steps

This table outlines the five primary scenarios for integrating SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA in the future text) capabilities into the Joule Studio environment.  Identify which flow best matches your current setup, whether you‚Äôre starting fresh or have existing SBPA or Joule subscriptions. This will immediately provide you with the exact action steps and critical notes required for a successful connection.

 

Starting Point

Key Action Steps

The partner is setting up both Joule and SBPA from scratch. 

  • Check the Prerequisites mentioned above. Verify the assignments.
  • Setup SBPA.  
    Setup SBPA Step by Step Video Guide
  • Both Joule and SBPA need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  • Connect Joule and SBPA by running the Joule Booster 
    Step by Step Video Guide for Joule Studio Activation SAP BTP
  • Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  • Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    • joule_extensibility
    • end_user 
  • Finalize trust/security configurations.
  • Verify entitlement/instance setup. 
  • Access Joule Studio.

The partner already has Joule (Booster provisioned) and now links the existing SBPA (it must be a build-default plan) for Joule Studio.

  1. Verify SBPA Prerequisites: Ensure SBPA entitlement is on the build-default plan (standard plan is not compatible).
  2. Setup SBPA.  
    Setup SBPA Step by Step Video Guide
  3. Both Joule and SBPA need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  4. Update Formation in Joule Global Account:
    1. Navigate to System Landscape -> Formations. 
    2. Select the existing Integration with Joule formation.
    3. Click Include Systems and select the SBPA subaccount.
    4. Check Enable Capability Deployment and finalize. 
  5. Wait for Formation Status to become Ready. 
  6. Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  7. Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    1. joule_extensibility
    2. end_user 

The partner has an existing SBPA (on the correct build-default plan) and now wants to add Joule.

  • Check the Prerequisites mentioned above for Joule. Verify the assignments.
  • Both Joule and SBPA need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  • Connect the new Joule to the existing SBPA by running the Joule Booster 
    Step by Step Video Guide for Joule Studio Activation SAP BTP
  • Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  • Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    • joule_extensibility
    • end_user 
  • Finalize trust/security configurations.
  • Verify entitlement/instance setup. 
  • Access Joule Studio.

The partner already has both services (on the correct plan); they just need to be linked for Joule Studio.

  • Check the Prerequisites mentioned above. Verify the assignments.
  • Both Joule and SBPA need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  • Update Formation in Joule Global Account:
    • Navigate to System Landscape -> Formations. 
    • Select the existing Integration with Joule formation.
    • Click Include Systems and select the SBPA subaccount.
    • Check Enable Capability Deployment and finalize. 
  • Wait for Formation Status to become Ready. 
  • Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  • Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    • joule_extensibility
    • end_user 

The partner has both, but SBPA is on the standard plan (requires an upgrade).

  • Upgrade SBPA to the correct plan (build-default).
  • Both Joule and SBPA need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  • Update Formation in Joule Global Account:
    • Navigate to System Landscape -> Formations. 
    • Select the existing Integration with Joule formation.
    • Click Include Systems and select the SBPA subaccount.
    • Check Enable Capability Deployment and finalize. 
  • Wait for Formation Status to become Ready. 
  • Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  • Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    • joule_extensibility
    • end_user 

How to Activate the Limited-Time Offer for Agent Builder

Once you have the prerequisites in place, you can take advantage of our promotional offer to explore the full potential of custom Joule agents. Here's how:

  1. Build Your Agent: The capability to build Joule agents will automatically appear in your lobby‚Äîno extra setup required.
  2. Test & Run for Free: Activate our limited-time promotional offer to run your custom agents with zero execution costs from now throughout January, 2026.

To activate the offer:

1. Navigate to the Control Tower in your SAP Build tenant.

2. Select AI Agent Builder Activation.

3. Enable agent builder, by accepting the terms and condition

FAQ & Common Pitfalls for Partners

Q1: I don't see the build-default plan for SAP Build in my TDD account. How do I get it?   Do not order a new paid subscription. Ensure you have the correct TDD account with BTP PAYG license. Then, go to your BTP Cockpit -> Service Marketplace. Find "SAP Build Process Automation" and create a new instance/subscription, making sure to select the build-default plan.

Q2: My Joule and SAP Build are in different Global Accounts. Is that a problem?  No, this is a common and supported partner scenario. The absolute requirement is that both global accounts' subaccounts use the same Cloud Identity Service (IAS) tenant for authentication.

Q3: I ran the booster, but Joule Studio doesn't appear, or I get an error when deploying. What's wrong? This is almost always one of three issues:

  1. Mismatched Identity Services: Your Joule and SBPA subaccounts are pointing to different IAS tenants.
  2. Incorrect SBPA Plan: You are still on the "standard" plan instead of "build-default".
  3. Incorrect Joule SKU: Make sure you have a correct Joule license under Joule service TDD SKU (8018168) at no cost. To be on the safe side, please contact with your account manager, making sure you have right SKU enabled.
  4. Missing Role Collections: Your user is missing the joule_extensibility and end_user roles in the Joule subaccount, or the necessary developer roles in the SBPA subaccount.

Q4: I followed the steps, but deployment still fails with an IdP error: This points to a deeper trust configuration issue. Verify the trust settings between your BTP subaccounts and the IAS tenant. Ensure the Integration with Joule Formation status is Ready. If the issue persists, we recommend logging a free Technical Advisory request via the SAP BTP Technical Advisory service for expert assistance.

Q5: I am experiencing an ongoing issue and require further assistance. How may I contact you? Please submit a free Technical Advisory request via the SAP BTP Technical Advisory service for expert assistance.

Helpful Resources for Setup and Activation 

  • How to get started with Joule Studio
  • Provisioning Joule Studio 
  • Enabling Joule Studio for existing customers 
  • Step by Step Video Guide for Joule Studio Activation SAP BTP
  • Reference Architecture for Joule Studio 
  • Activate Joule Studio in 5 Simple Steps

entry.title: From Insights to Action: Process Excellence by Combining Process Mining, Task Mining & Automation
entry.content:
In today‚Äôs enterprise landscapes, most companies already have plenty of process data, tactical insights ‚Äì and automation tools used; what‚Äôs often missing is a clear path from insight to action. Today, we will discuss how this gap can be closed using SAP Signavio, KYP.ai (SAP Partner), and SAP Build (including Joule Studio).

This post recaps and explains the storyline of the Devtoberfest session, including the demo:

This blog post is a joint work with @ManuelTae - Manuel Taechl (SAP Signavio), Jakub Lutter and Piotr Wisniewski (both: KYP.ai ‚Äì SAP Partner).

 

About SAP Signavio

SAP Signavio solutions help companies connect strategy to execution and increase business agility. In use at more than 3,000 global customers, the SAP Signavio Process Transformation Suite strengthens collaboration across business and IT, providing a clear map of how work gets done, which operational systems underlie that work, guidance on potential improvements, and the ability to model and assess the impact of any changes on customers and employees. By giving companies the ability to discover, understand, benchmark, improve, and transform their business processes, SAP Signavio accelerates the journey to digital transformation, operational excellence, and customer centricity. 

About KYP.ai, an SAP Partner (SAP Store listing)

KYP.ai is a Productivity Intelligence Platform that provides end-to-end visibility into how work gets done across people, processes, and technology. By combining data from digital footprints, business systems, and hardware, it uncovers inefficiencies, measures productivity objectively, and enables organizations to drive automation, performance, and engagement improvements across their operations.

KYP.ai is a cloud-based SaaS platform that gives enterprises end-to-end visibility into how work is actually done across people, processes, and technology. By continuously mining operational data from business systems and digital footprints, it identifies inefficiencies, bottlenecks, and opportunities where automation or AI can create value - helping organizations improve productivity, optimize workflows, and align operations with business objectives.

The value proposition centers on four major dimensions: uncovering ‚Äúwhere‚Äù work happens, understanding ‚Äúwho‚Äù does it, seeing ‚Äúhow‚Äù processes and technology are used, and defining ‚Äúwhat‚Äù needs to change to improve outcomes. By doing this, the platform helps organizations reduce manual effort, accelerate execution, improve engagement and drive business results such as margin improvement or cost-reduction.

About SAP Build

SAP Build is SAP's unified low-code and pro-code toolkit that empowers developers, IT professionals, and business experts to collaborate on creating applications and automating workflows. Built on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), the platform combines intuitive visual, drag-and-drop tools with intelligent AI assistance, enabling rapid deployment compared to traditional development. By integrating with SAP Signavio and KYP.ai, organizations can translate process insights into solutions while preserving their clean core architecture.

The approach combining visual development with optional pro-code customization allows SAP Build to handle both simple tasks and complex cross-system scenarios.

SAP Build recently introduced Joule Studio, a new solution that enables customers to create custom skills and AI agents for Joule, SAP's generative AI co-pilot, opening possibilities for intelligent automation and decision support.

 

The Big Idea: Connect Three Worlds

  1. Process mining (SAP Signavio Process Intelligence) reveals how core processes actually run in backend systems.
  2. Task & productivity mining (KYP.ai, SAP Partner) reveals what people really do on the frontend ‚Äì across apps, screens, and tools.
  3. Automation & AI (SAP Build Process Automation + Joule Studio) turn those insights into executable & actionable workflows and AI skills.

Instead of stopping at ‚Äúhere‚Äôs the bottleneck,‚Äù we go through a full loop:

  • Discover issues on a process level
  • Analyze tasks affecting processes at more tactical level (e.g. desktop tools used)
  • Identify automation candidates
  • Build and deploy automation scenarios
  • Expose them as reusable Joule skills to be used with Joule, SAP‚Äôs generative AI co-pilot
  • Measure ROI and improve continuously

High-level view:

 

Step 1: Understand the Process with SAP Signavio

The story starts where many transformation programs begin: with SAP Signavio.

Using Signavio Process Intelligence, the team ingests event logs from core transactional systems (for example, order-to-cash, purchase-to-pay, or shared-services workflows) and builds a digital twin of the process.

Signavio reveals things like:

  • Where cases get stuck (bottlenecks and long waiting times)
  • Rework loops and deviations from the happy path
  • Variants by region, business unit, or system

This is backend-centric: it shows what is happening inside the transactional systems, based on event logs and timestamps. That is incredibly valuable to get the full & detailed picture of the process. What can we add to that? It doesn‚Äôt fully explain why users behave as they do at the desktop level and what happens in tools which we don't analyze with process mining (e.g. Microsoft Outlook or Excel).

That‚Äôs where KYP.ai, an SAP Partner, comes in.

 

Step 2: Go Deeper with Task Mining via KYP.ai

KYP.ai complements SAP Signavio by looking at the frontend and user interactions:

  • Which applications employees switch between
  • How long they spend in each window
    • Identifying patterns for improvement based on copy-paste work, manual data entry, or repetitive clicks
  • How much time is idle or lost in context switching

While SAP Signavio answers:
‚ÄúWhat does the process look like in the system?‚Äù

KYP.ai complement the answer:
‚ÄúWhat are people actually doing on their screens to make this process happen?‚Äù

This combination can be used to:

  • Start from a problematic process area identified in SAP Signavio
  • Then zoom into individual tasks and micro-activities that make up that step
  • Quantify automation & agent proliferation potential based on volumes, repetition, and complexity

This is crucial for AI and automation: many of the best use cases live in fragmented, manual, cross-application work that backend logs alone cannot fully represent.

 

Step 3: Identify High-Value Automation Opportunities

Once both levels of insights are available, the team can prioritize automation candidates:

  • Tasks that occur frequently
  • Tasks that follow a repeatable pattern
  • Tasks that are error-prone or time-consuming
  • Tasks spanning multiple systems (SAP and non-SAP)

This outlines how task-level analytics from KYP.ai help filter for ‚Äúbig automation potential‚Äù tasks, not just any repetitive activity, while also turning the conversation with business stakeholders into something much more concrete:

  • ‚ÄúThis step costs X hours per week.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúAutomating it could free Y FTEs or reduce processing time by Z%.‚Äù

After opportunity identification and assessing the potential, we continue with the ground work for setting the stage for implementation. By using the data that we collected, we leverage the KYP.ai Concierge, an AI-powered assistant, to generate prompts for the agent building. These prompts define the role, workflow, integrations and actions documents needed to build the automation or the AI agent.

At this point, the story moves from analysis to execution.

 

Step 4: Create Process Automation scenarios with SAP Build

With clear candidates in hand, we shift to SAP Build on SAP Business Technology Platform.

Using SAP Build, developers and business technologists can:

  • Model approval flows and automations, both on the API and UI level
  • Integrate with SAP systems through prebuilt connectors, as well as non-SAP systems
  • Orchestrate human tasks and system tasks
  • Develop AI skills and custom Joule Agents (planned) with Joule Studio

Users can benefit from low-code, as well as

  • Instead of starting from a blank canvas, developers describe in natural language
    what the automation scenario should do
  • The tooling proposes a flow, which can then be refined, configured, and hardened
  • In our case, we are able to leverage the prompt that was generated by KYP.ai on the previous step.

This shortens the time from idea ‚Üí prototype ‚Üí tested flow and makes it much easier to iterate as more data from process and task mining comes in.

 

Step 5: Operationalize as Joule Skills and Agents

The last step is how to operationalize what has been built so that it can be:

  • Reused across different processes
  • Triggered by users through natural-language interaction with Joule, SAP‚Äôs generative AI co-pilot

This is where Joule Studio enter, allowing us to wrap automations and workflows as Joule skills ‚Äì self-contained capabilities that Joule can call.

  1. Use Joule Studio to define when and how these skills are used:
    • The goal of the agent
    • The tools/skills it can call (including Build automations)
    • Guardrails and policies for safe execution
  2. Expose those agents to end-users via SAP Fiori, SAP Start, SAP Work Zone, or other entry points.

Instead of a disparate process mining dashboard and a automation tool, there is a continuous improvement loop where:

  • Joule can detect a scenario (e.g., ‚Äúmany open items over threshold‚Äù)
  • Decide which skills to call
  • Execute workflows built in SAP Build as part of the skills
  • And write back outcomes into SAP systems, all under IT governance.

 

Step 6: Measure and improve continuously

Close the loop: Measure the impact of your automations, convert improvements into business value, and feed results back into process and task mining to prioritize the next cycle.

  • Use SAP Signavio to establish baseline KPIs and calculate the monetary potential of fixing the identified issues.
  • Drill into user-level detail with KYP.ai to validate root causes, quantify impact, and construct the prompt/spec for the SAP Build automation.
  • Build and deploy the automation in SAP Build, then wrap it as Joule skills/agents
  • Re-measure the same KPIs in SAP Signavio after deployment, convert improvements into realized monetary value, and publish results to stakeholders.
  • Use those validated results as a flywheel and secure stakeholder buy-in to prioritize the next set of opportunities and accelerate the next improvement cycle.

 

Why This Matters for Developers and Automation Teams

For developers, solution architects, and automation COEs, as well as process analysts, process owners and general set of business stakeholders, the session illustrates a few important shifts:

  • From point tools to an ecosystem
    Signavio, KYP.ai, SAP Build, and Joule Studio are not isolated. They reinforce each other: insight ‚Üí design ‚Üí automation ‚Üí execution.
  • From one-off bots to governed, reusable capabilities
    Instead of scripting ad-hoc automation tasks, the approach encourages building managed automations and Joule skills that sit inside a governed SAP BTP environment.
  • From generic AI hype to measurable outcomes
    Using KYP.ai to detect AI and automation opportunities at task level helps ensure AI is applied where it has clear, quantifiable impact.
  • From manual interpretation to data-driven prioritization
    Combining process mining and task mining means decisions on where to automate are backed by hard data ‚Äì not just stakeholder opinions.

 

How to Apply This Approach in Your Own Landscape

This is something developers can replicate in their own environment. A practical way to start:

  1. Pick a single business process
    Something with clear pain: order management, invoice handling, onboarding, or service requests.
  2. Run process mining with SAP Signavio
    Ingest event logs, build the process model, and identify the biggest delays and rework loops.
  3. Layer task mining with KYP.ai
    Focus on the most problematic steps. Capture desktop activity for a representative group of users and let KYP.ai highlight where time is really spent.
  4. Align with business and automation stakeholders
    Review the top 3‚Äì5 opportunities based on volume, feasibility, and expected impact.
  5. Prototype & create executable process automation scenarios in SAP Build
    Use prompt-based design to scaffold automations, then refine integrations, exception handling, and approvals.
  6. Wrap and scale via Joule skills and agents
    Add the most successful automations as Joule skills, so they can be called from natural-language interfaces and reused across teams.
  7. Measure, prove and iterate
    Use Signavio to capture baseline and post-deployment KPIs, publish these proof points to secure buy‚Äëin, and use them as a flywheel to prioritize the next cycle.

 

This integrated approach offers a pragmatic way to move from dashboards and analysis toexecutable automation and AI, powered by process & task insights, in our daily work.

It is less about any single tool and more about connecting insights to action in one continuous loop.

Thank you for your interest and please share your thoughts in the comments!

 

Related materials for further reading:

From Process Mining to Productivity Intelligence and Transformation

Enterprise Automation with SAP

KYP.ai SAP Store listing

entry.title: Santa learns lessons from the past: Successful Agentic AI needs an Event Driven Architecture
entry.content:
Most organisations realise that Agentic AI will become critical to their business. But there is still hesitation about giving up more control to these new agents. What if they make bad decisions, what if they do the wrong thing ?

I‚Äôve been in the technology industry for more decades than I may care to admit. Before joining SAP, I spent 14 years working within Financial Services and Capital Markets. It is interesting to reflect on those times. Many of the challenges back then remain the same today.

In Financial Services, the major players did not hesitate to innovate with new technology ‚Äì for them it was opportunity. Very early on they realised that trading in ‚Äúsimpler‚Äù financial instruments ( e.g. foreign exchange ) did not really need humans shouting excitedly at one another on the (tele)phone. That trading was quickly handed over to computers ‚Äì and whilst it was perhaps not AI by today‚Äôs definition, it was certainly algorithmic and it was most definitely autonomous. Billions still gets traded by these Agentic AI predecessors, all based on the lightning-fast decisions they make ( but operating within parameters and thresholds defined by humans that quantify the risk ).

Decisions are made as a result of an event that arises. Better decisions are made knowing the wider context of that event. Yes, context comes from data. Wider context ( surprise ! ) comes from more and different data. But all that data needs to be super up-to-date, and accurate.

Financial Services firms understood and solved this also. In a 24x7 global market, there is no window for a batch run to load data. Trading systems, market data providers, stock exchanges, market and credit risk systems and more, all needed to be wired together for simultaneous update of data. Plus, it needed to be robust and flexible to add-in other market participants and their systems also.

Most firms adopted architectures built around messaging-oriented middleware, with technologies like Enterprise Service Bus, Message Queue, and Event Bus amongst others, all being variations on a theme that today we call an Event Driven Architecture (EDA). Their appetite for speed pushed the technology to milli-second response times and super high-availability. Equally valuable was that the decoupled publisher-subscriber model allowed much faster and easier recovery if any of the participants in their expanded trading ecosystem did experience a failure.

Perhaps such requirements seem a bit extreme for many companies operating in other industry segments. But the world is increasingly real time for the majority of businesses, and as Agentic AI plays a bigger part in your daily operations, it may be time to reflect on these lessons.

To highlight this more tangibly, I thought about a festive ( but fictional ? ) example where the capabilities of an Event Driven Architecture could really make a difference. So grab a coffee, something sweet to eat ( save the gym for the New Year ) and read on ‚Ä¶

 

Santa Inc refactors gift delivery on an Event Driven Architecture

After decades relying on delivery to every home in sequence, Santa has realised this will no longer scale and he risks missing targets and some serious reputational damage. His operations used to be ok, but the customer base expands every year and getting to all of those in one day is now stretching the imagination.

Production used to be straightforward when it was just teddy bears, dolls, drums and toy trains, but now with games consoles, smartphones and other sophisticated presents it has become necessary to outsource to specialised manufacturing facilities in many countries. The elves have switched roles from sewing and carpentry to now managing supply chains, delivery bottlenecks and stock-outs ‚Äì they‚Äôre stressed and threatening to go on strike ! Managing stock and purchasing was much easier when children used to write letters, but now they post their wish lists on social media ‚Äì and keep changing their minds based on what is trending ! Logistics was never a problem ‚Äì Rudolph and the other reindeer managed through even the harshest weather. But now they are obliged to adhere to air-traffic control diversions and compulsory rest stops. Finally, when delivering a present, it was disappointing to find out  ( too late ) that the child had been naughty rather than nice. It meant carrying extra payload on the sleigh and unnecessary manufacturing and purchase costs.

Santa has an extensive IT landscape and ecosystem. But he realised even his magical powers were no longer the answer ‚Äì it was time to transform his operations. But not rip and replace ‚Ä¶ even with 364 quieter days, that would still be too much work. Besides, most of the individual systems did what they needed to do ‚Äì it was just they didn‚Äôt really react to each other that well. There was a lot of point-to-point connection between the production, inventory, CRM and other systems, with each repeatedly polling the other for updates ‚Äì a real spaghetti architecture. Adding new suppliers‚Äô systems into this landscape was slow. Recovering from any one system failure, having to replay lost transactions and regain overall confidence in stock quantities and delivery shipments an even bigger nightmare.

All of this was putting huge pressure on the elves. Santa has always been committed to his workforce, and he wanted the team to be happy and motivated. He looked to Agentic AI to help them, to manage the scale and complexity of supply chains. But like his elves, those AI agents would need to be super-smart, reactive, and always up to date with reliable data.

And then the lightbulb went on for Santa. He was reading this article about Event Driven Architecture and realised that would answer so many of these problems. The synchronous and repeated point-to-point communication is taken away. Instead, events are published asynchronously, with brokers distributing and guaranteeing them, to be consumed by any system that is interested ‚Äì instantly ( super-fast ) and simultaneously ( not each system in turn ). The spaghetti is now replaced by something more like a giant distributed smorgasbord in which everyone ( elves, agents and ecosystem partners ) can share all at once. NOTE: Santa was never a fan of spaghetti but does quite enjoy a good smorgasbord.

With an Event Driven Architecture, Santa could be much more responsive in his production runs and purchasing. Plus, new suppliers could be on-boarded quickly and easily to cater for peaks in toy popularity, as well as getting up-to-date pricing and costs across his ecosystem. On the big night itself, so many of those delivery headaches could now be mitigated. Travel and weather alerts would be provided immediately for dynamic routing updates ( and for Santa, every milli-second matters ). Add to this a real-time feed of naughty-or-nice monitoring data being gathered by event brokers across the globe ( some in very remote locations ) and made available to the dynamic routing algorithm as well as stock logistics teams ( Santa has an increasing network of warehouses that he needs to stop at ‚Äì he cannot carry everything on his sleigh ).

Santa and his Enterprise Architect ( another Elf ) looked at options and decided on SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh. Given that 84% of the world‚Äôs global commerce runs on SAP systems, and these already have high-value business events out-of-the-box, it was likely that much of Santa‚Äôs ecosystem could be easily included. Even for those using other vendors‚Äô applications, the solution was open to those via industry-standard protocols, plus it was possible to include custom-built events. It did not need rip and replace, and the system could scale by adding more brokers over time to create an event mesh. Even better, that same infrastructure could be used for other event use cases ( Santa wondered about moving into Travel & Entertainment for the rest of the year ‚Äì perhaps offering trips on the sleigh into low earth orbit ‚Äì he thought that might become popular ).

Whilst looking at SAP, his Enterprise Architect saw SAP Build Joule Studio, to create the AI agents. That seemed an obvious choice also ‚Äì many processes would run on SAP, the most relevant and up-to-date operational data resides there, plus it offered a large choice of LLMs across the major providers. Quick to get into production also ‚Äì because they rapidly needed to regain morale amongst the elves.

So that‚Äôs the story of how one globally recognised brand came to explore the benefits of an Event Driven Architecture. If you recognise any similarities to challenges within your own business operation, then I would invite you learn more here. Or, if you would like to see an example that the elves built earlier, then please do look at this short demo.

entry.title: Clean Core maturity and the new Extensibility Levels
entry.content:
For years, the architectural conversation around SAP S/4HANA seemed trapped in a rigid side.
On one side, the purist vision moving all development to side-by-side extensibility on SAP BTP. On the other side, the operational reality, where complex transactional logic and proximity to data made decoupling code technically expensive and sometimes unfeasible..

However, we often lost in this conversation: Clean Core... what's side-by-side... what's On-stack
Not so far back in time, we followed the 3-Tier Development Model. This framework tried to organize development into three tiers (Tier 1 for Cloud, Tier 2 with Wrappers, Tier 3 for Legacy).

While useful, there's a new pragmatic second generation framework: the Clean Core Level Concept
This new maturity model increases the availability of APIs and reduces the forced need for wrappers, incorporating classic ABAP use cases safely. But how does this translate into the modern architecture of Levels A, B, C, and D?

Level A: The Gold Standard (On-stack & Side-by-side)
Level A doesn't force you off-stack. It represents extensions that rely exclusively on stable, public interfaces backed by stability. Is agnostic to the deployment environment:

Side-by-side Extensions: Decoupled extensions running on the Business Technology Platform. This ecosystem allows for SAP Build (low-code/pro-code), CAP (Java/Node.js), and ABAP Cloud (Steampunk) to create scalable apps and automations

On-stack Extensions: Created inside SAP S/4HANA Cloud (either as Key User Extensions or Developer Extensions). This validates that building tightly coupled logic within the S/4HANA it's ok, provided that released technologies like RAP (RESTful ABAP Programming) and CDS Views are used. So that by using of released APIs and strict syntax checks, you can build tightly coupled logic (essential for transactional integrity) without creating technical debt

Level B: The Pragmatism of "Classic APIs"
Unlike Level A, which relies on stability contracts, Level B uses Classic APIs and frameworks. While not strictly "Cloud" capable, these are upgrade-stable.
You can identify these in the Cloudification Repository. Object frameworks such as SAPscript, and ALE/IDoc integrations fall into this category. This provides a critical "safe harbor," allowing to leverage proven legacy technologies without facing immediate refactoring pressure

Level C: Risk Management and Changelogs
When business reality demands the use of internal SAP objects for legacy scenarios, we enter Level C. Unlike the previous levels, there is an upgrade risk here. To mitigate it, SAP provides the Changelog for SAP Objects, a tool that allows you to identify incompatible changes early and plan proactive actions. Although not the preferred approach, it is a valid option if managed with wrappers to isolate the dependency.

Level D : The red line (Technical Debt)
Any extension that uses non-recommended patterns, such as direct modifications to the standard, direct writing to tables, or Implicit Enhancements, falls into this category. This represents the highest risk of technical debt and must be rigorously blocked using ABAP Test Cockpit (ATC) checks. These patterns bypass standard logic and guarantee disruption during upgrades

Extensions objects are classified as unfit for customer use (marked as "noAPI" in the Cloudification Repository) 

By understanding Levels (A, B, C, D) we can make architectural decisions that balance technical purity with operational reality, prioritizing business stability and flexibility.... But Important!!: Beyond the levels, a Clean Core strategy requires governance. The fundamental principle is: Extensions must be avoided when possible. Before, we must to evaluate if standard functionality covers the process. If the extension is inevitable, we must ensure that extensions don't break Upgrades
To decide between an On-stack or Side-by-side implementation, customers should use the SAP Application Extension Methodology. This methodology helps to define a custom extension strategy. It addresses challenges like "clean core" by offering a structured, standard approach. This ensures a common understanding and terminology and it allows to assess technical options and make informed decisions to build an extension framework for your organization.

---
Bookmark this SAP Note: 3578329 - Frameworks, Technologies and Development Patterns in Context of Clean Core Extensibility 
Official list of framework and technology classifications that will tell you what is Level A, B, C, or D

New Cloudification Repository Viewer for Clean Core Governance and Development
https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/new-cloudification-repository-viewer-for-clean-core-governance-and/ba-p/14236110

entry.title: Agent builder in Joule Studio is now generally available: Build your own Joule agents today!
entry.content:
Traditional rule-based automation struggles to keep up with modern business processes, which are constantly evolving and becoming more complex. Agentic AI helps handle dynamic workflows with adaptability. As previewed at TechEd 2025, the agent builder capability in Joule Studio empowers developers to create context-aware Joule agents that can plan, reason, and execute multi-step processes across diverse systems, with self-learning and high adaptability, unlocking new levels of productivity and efficiency across your enterprise. 

Today, building on the release of skill builder in Joule Studio earlier in 2025, we‚Äôre excited to make the agent builder in Joule Studio generally available. The agent builder enables developers to create Joule agents that are tailored to their unique business requirements and break cross-ecosystem silos and reduce barriers to AI adoption. This capability is powered by the same underlying agent framework and runtime that ready-to-use Joule agents do. That offers built-in data protection guardrails, deep reasoning models, and context retention across tasks for scalable, secure multi-agent executions.  

In this post, I‚Äôll take you through what‚Äôs being released as part of the agent builder experience, how to create Joule agents in no time, and resources to help you get started. We‚Äôll explore common use cases to transform business workflows with agentic AI and provide visibility into our roadmap. Together, these insights will help you move from isolated AI experiments to scalable, production-grade agents that deliver real business impact. 

 Key highlights of the release: 

  • AI-guided development: Generate Joule Agents using natural language with vibe coding  
  • Model Context Protocol (MCP) support: Connect to external tools and applications with support for MCP 
  • Multi-agent orchestration: Add subagents as a tool to allow agents to invoke them for planning and executing complex, multi-step workflows 
  • Ground agents in business context: Drive reliable outcomes by grounding agent reasoning in your documents  
  • Leverage your existing SAP Build content: Embed pre-built custom skills, automations, and actions to accelerate time to value  
  • Human in the loop: ensure human oversight for critical decisions and approvals 

"With Joule Studio, agentic innovation moves closer to the heart of operations. At KPMG, we‚Äôre helping to shape trusted solutions that transform business context into measurable value by building specialized AI agents for fulfillment orchestration, supply chain management, and more‚Äù.  

 - Valentino K√∂ster, Global Head of SAP360 Program & AI, KPMG AG WPG, Germany 

 

Meet Agent builder - the next evolution for Joule Studio  

Joule Studio is a capability in SAP Build that allows developers to design Joule agents and skills with a low code, no code canvas. Since it is part of SAP Build, Joule Studio has native access to all your connectors, automations, apps, and actions - enabling you to reuse artifacts, leverage shared APIs, and operate within a single governance framework. The agents created in Joule Studio work across their on-prem solutions including S/4 HANA and SAP ECC, SAP Cloud solutions, and third-party APIs and applications. Joule Studio leverages SAP Cloud Identity Services so that your agents have the right authorization and authentication for tasks that they are supposed to complete. It also enforces principal propagation, meaning the user‚Äôs identity in Joule is passed through end-to-end so that any triggered skill or agent runs strictly within that user‚Äôs security context, applying the same authorization checks and access restrictions. Moreover, it is integrated with Joule and AI core to seamlessly expose custom agents through Joule, empower agents with deep reasoning through models, and ground them in business data with document grounding.  

Image 1: Joule Studio Marketecture

 

Now let's dive into key features of agent builder in Joule Studio that simplifies the creation of powerful agents.

AI-guided development experience to fast-track deployment of AI agents 

Joule Studio brings AI guidance directly into the agent builder experience. Developers can describe what they need in plain language, and the Joule copilot responds with tailored suggestions for agent definitions, tools, and configuration options.  For instance, when building a logistics-focused agent, Joule may recommend a relevant Joule skill to fetch real-time stock levels and low-stock thresholds. This bridges the gap between simplicity and flexibility - empowering teams to innovate faster while maintaining full control over agent behavior.   

 

Image 2: AI-guided development for building agents in Joule Studio

 

Support for Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers for enhanced interoperability  

A major enhancement in Joule Studio is the newly added support for MCP - an open, standardized protocol that streamlines how AI agents interact with external systems. Instead of working within isolated applications, agents can now operate seamlessly across different platforms. 

In Joule Studio, you can connect agents to external MCP servers via destinations, configured in BTP Cockpit. That enables custom agents to tap into tools and services outside the SAP ecosystem. For instance, a support agent built in Joule Studio can create or update purchase requests in an external purchase requisition tool that exposes its capabilities via MCP. This level of interoperability turns AI agents into intelligent orchestrators that can handle end-to-end workflows across multiple systems without requiring custom integrations or heavy engineering effort. 

 

Image 3: Connecting custom Joule agents with third-party tools and applications using MCP

 

Creating multi-agent systems for complex workflows 

Joule Studio enables developers to build a modular ‚ÄúAI workforce‚Äù by allowing agents to be added as callable tools within other agents. Each agent can delegate tasks to specialized sub-agents built in Joule Studio and collaborate to solve much larger or more complex problems. This orchestration modularity avoids relying on a single, monolithic agent to handle everything and ensures clearer separation of responsibilities, simplifies testing and maintenance, and makes it far easier to scale agentic solutions as business needs evolve. 

For example, an ‚ÄúInventory Restocking Agent‚Äù can act as an orchestrator and delegate tasks to specialized sub-agents such as a ‚ÄúContract Compliance Checker‚Äù to validate that each proposed restocking order aligns with supplier contract terms before it is placed. These specialized sub-agents are built with Joule Studio and serve as reusable resources for other agents.  

Image 4: Adding other custom Joule agents built in Joule Studio as tools for other Joule agents 

From an idea to an agent in few simple steps 

Joule agents solve complex business challenges dynamically and intelligently. They excel in planning, reasoning, and autonomous execution, seamlessly navigating unknown paths with informed decision-making. Following are the key components of the agent definition:  

Goals and instructions: these act as job description for the agent and helps it understand its role and responsibilities  

Planning and reasoning: Large Language Models (LLMs) help agents plan and reason through the complex scenario   

Execution: agents need tools to interact with their environment and execute. 

Agent builder in Joule Studio allows designing a Joule agent with all the needed components in a low code/no code canvas that empowers both professional and citizen developers, allowing for scalability, governance, and alignment with SAP‚Äôs clean-core principles. 

The core steps include: 

  • Create a Project in SAP Build: Access SAP Build lobby and select project type for Joule Studio: ‚ÄòJoule agent and skill‚Äô. After filling out meta data for Joule Studio project, within that, create AI Agent as an artifact. 
  • Add Metadata: Assign name and description for the agent. This meta data helps Joule to identify the right agent for the job based on user intent. 
  • Define expertise and instructions: these provide the agent with context on its role and guide the agent‚Äôs behavior and decision-making. 
  • Configure tools: Select and configure the tools the agent can use to execute:  
  • MCP Servers: connect agents to external tools and applications exposed via MCP server, using destinations configured in BTP Cockpit. 
  • Sub agents as a tool: add other custom agents designed in Joule Studio as tools for one another, defining multi-agent systems for complex workflows. 
  • Joule skills: for executing rule-based, deterministic tasks 
  • Document grounding: create resource groups in AI Core with your business documents, then add those resource groups as tools to your agent in Joule Studio. This grounds agents in business context needed for a workflow. For example, adding carrier contracts to a logistic agent for making informed decisions on carriers for optimizing shipment transport. 
  • Human in the Loop: human oversight is ensured by default for critical decisions and compliance. 
  • Calculator: for mathematical calculations 
  • Testing: debug the agent in Joule Studio before deployment to see each step of its reasoning, actions and data flow, using mock conversations, tool-call scenarios and edge cases. 
  • Release and deploy: Once validated, deploy the agent into the designated environment, making it accessible to authorized users via Joule or other configured channels. 

This modular approach not only accelerates development but also embeds governance controls - such as tool usage boundaries and human-in-the-loop checkpoints - directly into the design process, ensuring enterprise-grade reliability and flexibility. See the demo below: 

 

‚ÄúWith Joule Studio, we could build powerful agents in three weeks. It is an intuitive, no‚Äëcode environment that enables system connectivity across SAP and non‚ÄëSAP critical environments, for a hybrid landscapes where data resides in multiple modules.‚Äù  

 - Gianluca Simeone, VP - Global SAP CTIO and Gen-AI Leader at Capgemini 

Use cases for custom Joule agents 

Joule agents are ideal for solving complex, dynamic problems that traditional automation come short in solving. They excel in scenarios where planning, reasoning, and adaptive execution are critical. Let‚Äôs explore some of common use cases for creating custom Joule agents: 

  • Payroll variance analysis: An agent can simplify payroll variance analysis, a critical process for financial control and compliance, by instantly determining the source of variances, confirming allowances align with company policies, andreducing resolution time. This provides managers and payroll specialists with visibility into deviations, ensuring accuracy and confidence in payroll operations. Read more. 
  • Customer purchasing behavior analysis: An agent can help sales representatives quickly identify anomalies in customer purchasing behavior and assist in responding proactively to improve customer experience. Read more 
  • Inventory management: An agent can enable manufacturers and retailers to reduce losses from aging and obsolete inventory by turning inventory management into a proactive, data-driven process. For example, an agent can scan SAP S/4HANA data to detect early signs of obsolescence, categorize risk, and suggest actions such as redistribution or markdowns. Read more. 
  • Q&A: An agent can interpret complex queries by retrieving accurate information instantly from enterprise systems, documents, and knowledge bases to surface the most relevant insights, and guide users step-by-step through processes. This reduces the dependency on manual lookups and helps users get the right answers quickly and consistently. Read more. 
  • Logistics: An agent can optimize delivery routes based on real-time traffic data, weather conditions, and carrier availability, enhancing efficiency and reducing transportation costs.  

‚ÄúNestle, SAP, and IBM worked together on a supply chain Agentic AI PoC. With the agent builder capability in Joule Studio, we created this POC bringing in data from SAP and non-SAP sources to create an agent that will automate our complex Order fulfillment processes‚Äù   

- Pablo Nill, Sr Product Group Manager, Nestle     

Image 5: Concept of a custom AI agent created to optimize logistics of a shipment

 

Looking ahead 

This is only the beginning. We‚Äôre working on bringing following new capabilities in the agent builder next year as part of our roadmap: 

  •  System-Triggered Agents: Enable agents to activate automatically based on system events, API triggers or schedule reducing manual intervention and accelerating workflows. 
  • Agent-to-Agent Collaboration (A2A): Allow agents to collaborate with third-party agents, coordinating tasks and sharing context for complex, multi-step processes. 
  • Agent Extensibility: Adapt ready-to-use Joule agents by adding tools and pre- and post-processing logic in an upgrade-safe way, ensuring flexibility without compromising stability. 

We‚Äôre running a limited-time promotion that lets your agents run at no cost until end of Jan 2026. Don't miss out on this opportunity and see following resources to help you get started: 

  • How to Get Started with Joule Studio 
  • Learn how to activate Joule Studio 
  • Joule Studio Goes Live: Answers to Your Top Questions 
  • Customer testimonial (Uniper) 
  • Watch the on-demand webinar for a deeper dive in agent builder 
  • Podcast 

Meanwhile, if you have any questions, contact our product experts: @Kvidit , @maria_kondratyeva , @soufia , @jenie , @shamichi , @eric_solberg , and @noravonthenen.

entry.title: Part 2: Building the Intelligent Maintenance Fulfillment Agent in Joule Studio
entry.content:
In my previous blog post, we laid the groundwork by creating, configuring, and deploying individual Joule Skills  (GetMaintenanceOrderDetails, GetOperationComponents, GetMaterialStockLevels, etc.) . These skills allow Joule to "talk" to our backend and perform specific tasks like fetching maintenance order details or checking material stock levels.However, a maintenance planner doesn't just want raw data; they want answers to complex questions like, "Can I finish this job today based on what's in the warehouse?" In this post, we move beyond individual skills. We will build a Joule Agent- the "brain" that orchestrates those skills to provide intelligent, end-to-end validation. 

Step 7: Create the Joule Agent Project 

  1. Go to your Joule Skill Project > Overview tab 
  2. Click Create > Joule Agent. 
  3. Fill in the following: 
    • Name: e.g., Maintenance Fulfillment Validator 
    • Identifier: maintenanceFulfillmentValidator 
    • Description: e.g., Agent to check if maintenance orders can proceed based on material stock levels .
  4. Click Create

Step 8: Add Expertise & Instructions 

After creation, you‚Äôll land on the agent editor screen: 

Add a clear Expertise Summary to describe what your agent is good at (e.g., "Validating maintenance order fulfillment based on stock availability") 

In the Instructions section, define how the agent should behave: 

Step 9: Configure Model Settings & Tools 

Scroll down to the Model Settings section: 

  1. Choose your LLM Provider (e.g., SAP Joule Model or other available models) 
  2. Click Add Tool.

     

  3.  From the dropdown, select Joule Skill.
  4. You will now see a list of all the skills created in your project 
  5. Add all the relevant skills for your use case: 
    • GetMaintenanceOrderDetails 
    • GetOrderOperations 
    • GetOperationComponents 
    • GetMaterialDetails 
    • GetMaterialStockLevels 

 

Alternative Approach: Using Vibe Coding

Joule Studio offers an innovative capability called vibe coding that allows developers to define agents using natural language rather than manually wiring every step.

Instead of explicitly defining the orchestration logic, you describe the agent's goal, available skills, and constraints‚Äîand Joule Studio generates the agent flow for you. This makes vibe coding particularly useful for rapid prototyping, experimentation, and learning how agents reason across multiple skills.

In this section, we will recreate the same stock validation agent built earlier, but this time using vibe coding, to demonstrate how quickly an end-to-end agent can be assembled once the fundamentals are understood. 

Step 10: The "Vibe Coding" Alternative ‚Äì Speed to Market 

  1. Open the Assistant: Click the Joule Chat icon inside the Agent Editor. 

     

  2. Prompt the Vibe:  "Create an agent that is able to validate maintenance orders, check material stock, and recommend actions to ensure fulfillment. 
    Include all available skills and use all the information you have (from the description and skills) to formulate expertise, fully describe the process in instructions and additional context.‚Äù 

     

  3. Confirm Generation: Joule generates the Instructions and Expertise automatically. It also suggests linking the Skills we built in Part 1. 
    1. Open the newly created agent in your project. 
    2. Review the Instructions and Expertise sections to confirm that Joule has generated a detailed, end-to-end logic for maintenance order validation. 
  4. Verify that the previously created skills are automatically added as Tools for the agent. 

     

  5. Refining the Vibe (Continuous Improvement): The true power of vibe coding is that you can iteratively add or refine your prompt based on what changes you need in your agent.
    1.  Iterative Improvement Example: Return to the Joule Chat assistant and provide additional refinement prompts: 
    2. Prompt 2 (Enhanced Instructions): "Update the current instructions of the Maintenance Fulfillment Agent to be highly detailed in each step. This includes requesting the order ID if not given, then extracting all information about the order including its operations. For each operation the components shall be extracted and verified by analyzing stock levels and details like open purchase orders, blocks etc. A fulfillment decision should be made depending on the analysis with a full explanation." 
    3. Review the Updates:Observe how Joule automatically updates the Instructions section with more granular step-by-step logic.

Step 11: Configure Skill Access Settings 

Regardless of whether you created your agent manually or through vibe coding, you need to configure how skills can be accessed: 

Important Configuration: 

  1. Navigate to each skill that your agent uses as a tool 
  2. Locate the toggle "Allow skill to be started directly by a user" 
  3. Ensure this toggle is turned OFF for all skills used by your agent 
  4. This configuration: 
    • Allows the agent to call skills programmatically 
    • Prevents direct user access to individual skills 
  5. Ensures users interact with the intelligent agent rather than raw skill outputs. 

     

Step 12: Test Your Agent (Before Deployment) 

Before deploying your agent to production, Joule Studio provides a built-in testing feature that allows you to validate your agent's functionality without deployment: 

  1. In the Agent Editor, locate the Test panel or Test button 

     

  2. Select your private environment which you can create in Environment in the control panel. 
  3. Click continue.

This opens an interactive testing interface within Joule Studio where you can ask your question to the agent.

Once you start testing your agent, you can observe how it intelligently orchestrates multiple skills to fulfill complex requests.

 

Example Prompts to Test the Agent 

  1. ‚ÄúCan order 25 be fulfilled with current stock?‚Äù 
  2. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs blocking maintenance order 20?‚Äù 
  3. ‚ÄúIs order 1 ready to proceed or does it need follow-up?‚Äù 
  4. ‚ÄúWhy is order 4 still pending?‚Äù 
  5. ‚ÄúWhich materials are causing delays in maintenance order 24?‚Äù 
  6. ‚ÄúIs material M-45678 available in stock?‚Äù 
  7. ‚ÄúHow much of material M-98765 do we have?‚Äù 
  8. ‚ÄúDo we have enough materials for order with ID 10?‚Äù 

 

Step 13: Release, Version, and Deploy the Agent 

The deployment process for Joule Agents follows the same workflow as deploying Joule Skills. 

For detailed deployment steps, refer to "Step 6: Release and Deploy Joule Skills" from my previous blog post: How to Build Stock Validation Skills in Joule Studio 

Quick Summary: 

  1. Release: Click Release to version your agent 
  2. Navigate: Go to Project > Versions 
  3. Deploy: Click Deploy 
  4. Configure Deployment: 
    1. Select your Environment: Use the environment you created in Step 2 of the previous blog post 
    2. Select your Destination: Choose the appropriate destination 
    3. Ensure the destination is associated with your chosen environment 
  5. Confirm: Click Deploy 

The "Last Mile": Moving your Agent to Production 

Once your agent is Active, you‚Äôll want to see it in action within the actual Joule Chat experience (e.g., in the BTP Cockpit or an SAP LoB application). To "productionize" your agent, follow these critical configuration steps: 

  1. Check your Formation: Ensure your BTP Formation is configured correctly in the BTP Cockpit and includes the necessary SAP LoB Application. 
  2. Enable Joule Shared: In the SAP Build app, navigate to the Environment level > Joule Tab. Under settings, enable Share Environment Capabilities. This allows the agent to be "seen" by the broader Joule tenant. 

     

  3. The Sync Window: After deploying to a shared environment, it typically takes about 30 minutes for the background synchronization to complete. 

Step 16: Advanced Integration - MCP Servers (Optional) 

For enterprise scenarios requiring external system integration beyond SAP, Joule Studio supports Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers as additional tools for your agent. 

What MCP Servers Enable: 

  • Connect to external APIs and third-party services 
  • Integrate with non-SAP databases and systems 
  • Build cross-system orchestration workflows 
  • Extend agent capabilities beyond SAP ecosystem 

High-Level Setup Process: 

  1. BTP Configuration: Create and configure MCP server destinations in your BTP Cockpit 
  2. Joule Studio Integration: Add the configured destinations to your Joule Studio environment 
  3. Agent Integration: Reference MCP servers in your agent alongside Joule Skills 

Wrapping Up Part 2: From Skills to Intelligent Orchestration 

In this second part of our Joule Studio blog , we've elevated individual skills into an intelligent agent that can orchestrate multiple capabilities seamlessly. Your Maintenance Fulfillment Validator agent now understands complex maintenance scenarios, coordinates between different skills, and provides comprehensive responses about order fulfillment and stock validation. 

Key Achievements: 

  • Traditional Agent Building: Step-by-step manual configuration of expertise, instructions, and skill orchestration 
  • Vibe Coding Innovation: Rapid agent creation using natural language prompts - demonstrating how Joule Studio can automatically generate agent logic, expertise, and instructions 
  • Multi-Skill Orchestration: Your agent intelligently coordinates multiple skills to provide holistic business insights 

Vibe Coding Advantage: The introduction of vibe coding shows how Joule Studio is evolving to accelerate development cycles. What traditionally required manual configuration can now be achieved through conversational AI, making agent development more accessible and faster. 

With both individual skills, intelligent agents, and rapid prototyping capabilities in your toolkit, you're now equipped to build sophisticated automation solutions that can handle complex business scenarios with human-like intelligence. 

Looking Ahead: The Future of Joule Studio Agents 

As Joule Studio continues to evolve, exciting capabilities are on the roadmap that will further transform how businesses leverage AI automation: 

  • Agent-to-Agent (A2A) Communication: Enabling agents to collaborate and coordinate with each other for complex multi-domain workflows 
  • Agent Extensibility: Advanced customization capabilities allowing deeper integration with your specific business processes 
  • System-Triggered Agents: Proactive agents that respond automatically to business events and system triggers, moving beyond user-initiated interactions 

The foundation you've built today positions you perfectly to leverage these advanced capabilities as they become available, creating even more sophisticated and autonomous business solutions.
